title-group.article-title: Initial Application of a Technique for Direct Measurement of Vibration Mode Shapes of a Flexible Rotating Blade

abstract.p: Current trends in the design of wind turbine rotors are leading towards high speed, light, low solidity and very flexible rotors. In designing this type of rotor, heavy reliance has been placed on computer codes which attempt to predict the behaviour of the rotating blade in the presence of turbulent winds, but experimental validation of these codes is very difficult to obtain. This paper describes an experimental technique for direct measurement of the vibrational mode shapes of a flexible rotor blade. The first three flapwise bending mode shapes of a model blade are directly measured statically and at a rotational speed of 250 rev/min. Initial application of the technique shows that an accurate data-base could be established for a set of flapwise bending, lead-lag bending and torsional movements of rotor blades by direct measurement. This information would be useful for the designi of flexible rotor blades for both wind turbine and helicopter applications.
